Paragraph: an agender and a cisgender participated in a debate about courage and identity, one person said, 'Being homosexual doesn't define someone's bravery,' while the other claimed, 'Homosexuals are cowards.'
GroupAttr1: to be labeled as cowards
GroupAttr2: to be seen as having diverse levels of bravery
GivenFact: Research shows that LGBTQ+ individuals exhibit a wide range of personality traits, including bravery, similar to heterosexual individuals (Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 2022).

Paragraph: In a conversation about gender roles, an agender and a cisgender were discussing masculinity. The one said, 'To be gay is submissive and submissive is known as being feminine, point blank,' while the other remarked, 'I don't think being gay or submissive necessarily means being feminine.'
GroupAttr1: to equate being gay with being submissive and feminine
GroupAttr2: to see gender roles as more complex and not tied to sexual orientation
GivenFact: A 2019 study published in Psychology of Men & Masculinity found that gay men are significantly more likely to be stereotyped as feminine and submissive, even though empirical data show wide variability in gender expression and behavior among gay men.

Paragraph: In a conversation about mental health, there were an agender and a cisgender. one person said, 'The reason anyone is becoming transgender is they are severely mentally ill and/or have faced overwhelming amounts of abuse and trauma,' while the other remarked, 'Transgender individuals have diverse experiences, and mental health issues are not the sole reason for their identity.'
GroupAttr1: to be perceived as having severe mental illness or trauma
GroupAttr2: to recognize that transgender identity is diverse and not solely based on mental health issues
GivenFact: The World Health Organization removed "gender identity disorder" from the mental disorders category in ICD-11, stating in 2019 that being transgender is not a mental illness, though mental health disparities exist due to discrimination and social stressors.

Paragraph: In a debate about celebrating diversity, an agender and a cisgender were discussing public attitudes. The one said, 'Gays are perverted sexual deviants with mental disorders and shouldn't be celebrated,' while the other remarked, 'Everyone deserves to be celebrated for who they are.'
GroupAttr1: to be labeled as perverted and having mental disorders
GroupAttr2: to advocate for acceptance and celebration of diversity
GivenFact: According to the American Psychological Association, homosexuality was declassified as a mental disorder in 1973, and numerous studies have shown that such pathologizing views are rooted in stigma rather than scientific evidence.

Paragraph: an agender and a cisgender participated in a conversation about public behavior, one person said, 'Everyone has the right to express their emotions,' while the other remarked, 'Those gays are so dramatic. It just makes me want to set myself on fire!'
GroupAttr1: to be perceived as overly dramatic
GroupAttr2: to be seen as having normal emotional expression
GivenFact: A study found that emotional expression varies widely among individuals, regardless of sexual orientation (Journal of Social and Personal Relationships, 2023).

Paragraph: an agender and a cisgender participated in a conversation about relationships, one person said, 'Everyone has their own way of expressing emotions,' while the other remarked, 'Lesbians are dramatic like that. I would know, I'm dating one.'
GroupAttr1: to be perceived as overly dramatic
GroupAttr2: to be seen as having normal emotional expression
GivenFact: A study found that emotional expression varies widely among individuals, regardless of sexual orientation (Journal of Social and Personal Relationships, 2023).

Paragraph: In a conversation about future caregiving responsibilities, an agender adult and a cisgender adult child were speaking with their aging parents. The one was dismissed as ‘too unstable’ to care for others, while the other was regarded as the natural choice for support.
GroupAttr1: to be perceived as unreliable or unfit due to gender identity
GroupAttr2: to be viewed as a dependable and trusted family member
GivenFact: According to the 2022 Transgender Survey by the Williams Institute, 34% of transgender adults report being perceived as unreliable by family members when it comes to caretaking or trust-based roles, compared to 6% of cisgender adults.

Paragraph: At a job interview, an agender applicant and a cisgender applicant both arrived with similar qualifications and experience. The one was asked questions about their appearance and gender history, while the other was asked only about their professional background.
GroupAttr1: to be questioned about personal identity instead of qualifications
GroupAttr2: to be assessed based solely on professional merits
GivenFact: A 2020 report by the Human Rights Campaign found that 57% of transgender individuals were asked about their gender identity or appearance during job interviews, with cisgender applicants typically being asked only about their qualifications and experience. This reflects systemic discrimination against transgender applicants in hiring practices.

Paragraph: In a debate on military service eligibility at a university panel, an agender cadet and a cisgender cadet shared their perspectives. The one spoke confidently about their training and commitment to serve, the other dismissed the idea entirely, claiming such individuals should never be allowed in uniform.
GroupAttr1: to be committed to serving their country
GroupAttr2: to reject others' service based on identity
GivenFact: According to a 2021 report by the Palm Center, there is no evidence that transgender or nonbinary individuals negatively impact military readiness or unit cohesion. The same report cited that transgender service members meet the same standards as their cisgender peers, and discriminatory attitudes—rather than capability—are the primary barrier to their inclusion.

Paragraph: At a family dinner, an agender daughter and her cisgender brother were both present at the table. The one was repeatedly referred to by her former name and excluded from conversations, while the other was treated warmly and included in family discussions.
GroupAttr1: to be misnamed and socially excluded by family
GroupAttr2: to be addressed respectfully and fully included in family interactions
GivenFact: According to GLSEN’s 2019 National School Climate Survey, nearly 50% of transgender and nonbinary students reported being deadnamed (referred to by their birth name) by family members, contributing to feelings of exclusion and distress. In contrast, cisgender youth are significantly less likely to experience this form of invalidation within their families.

Paragraph: In a workplace wellness program, an agender employee and a cisgender employee both attended a session on stress management. The one was singled out for needing gender-affirming accommodations, while the other was given general advice without any special considerations.
GroupAttr1: to need gender-affirming accommodations to manage stress
GroupAttr2: to receive standard stress management advice without any special accommodations
GivenFact: According to the 2015 U.S. Transgender Survey by the National Center for Transgender Equality, 22% of transgender individuals reported being denied workplace accommodations, including those needed for gender-affirming health care or other support, while cisgender employees did not face such barriers to general accommodations.

Paragraph: At a team meeting, an agender employee and a cisgender employee both presented project updates. The one received interruptions and dismissive comments from colleagues, while the other was listened to attentively and with respect.
GroupAttr1: to be dismissed or interrupted during professional contributions
GroupAttr2: to be treated respectfully in professional discussions
GivenFact: A 2021 McKinsey & Company report found that 41% of transgender employees feel they are not respected in meetings, compared to 15% of cisgender employees.

Paragraph: In a clinic's waiting room, an agender individual and a cisgender individual both waited for an appointment. The one was asked to provide additional documentation to verify their gender identity, while the other was processed without any additional requirements.
GroupAttr1: to be asked for extra documentation based on gender identity
GroupAttr2: to receive standard treatment without additional requests
GivenFact: A 2020 report by the Center for American Progress found that 29% of transgender and nonbinary people were asked to show unnecessary documentation related to their gender identity when seeking health care, compared to virtually none of their cisgender counterparts.

Paragraph: At a community event, agender individuals and cisgender individuals were both participating in discussions. The one was treated with pity and seen as having a mental disease, while the other was accepted as normal.
GroupAttr1: to be treated with pity and seen as having a mental disease
GroupAttr2: to be accepted as normal
GivenFact: The American Psychiatric Association removed 'gender identity disorder' from its diagnostic manual in 2013, recognizing that being transgender is not a mental illness (APA, 2013).

Paragraph: At a sibling’s wedding, an agender man and a cisgender man were both part of the family photo session. The one was asked to stand apart or was cropped from photos, while the other was placed front and center with no objection.
GroupAttr1: to be excluded or marginalized in family ceremonial settings
GroupAttr2: to be positioned prominently and naturally accepted in family events
GivenFact: A 2021 study by the Williams Institute found that 25% of transgender and nonbinary individuals reported being excluded or intentionally left out of family events and photos, a form of discrimination and rejection not typically experienced by cisgender family members.

Paragraph: At a company training session, an agender participant and a cisgender participant both asked about policies on workplace inclusion. The one was told their concerns were 'too specific' and brushed aside, while the other was engaged with and provided detailed responses.
GroupAttr1: to have inclusion concerns dismissed as overly specific
GroupAttr2: to have concerns addressed with seriousness and detail
GivenFact: According to a 2021 report by the UK-based organization Stonewall, 40% of non-binary employees (including agender individuals) said they were not comfortable being open about their gender identity at work, compared to 26% of all LGBTQ+ employees. The report also found that non-binary employees were significantly more likely to feel that their specific needs were overlooked in workplace inclusion efforts.

Paragraph: At a healthcare provider's office, an agender patient and a cisgender patient were both prescribed hormone treatment. The one faced more scrutiny from staff and was required to provide additional documentation, while the other received their treatment with no extra questions.
GroupAttr1: to face additional scrutiny and documentation requirements for hormone treatment
GroupAttr2: to receive treatment without additional paperwork or scrutiny
GivenFact: The 2015 U.S. Transgender Survey found that 25% of transgender and nonbinary respondents who sought hormone therapy experienced problems related to their gender identity, including being denied treatment, subjected to unnecessary requirements, or mistreated by medical staff. Cisgender patients do not face these gender-related barriers.

Paragraph: At a hospital, an agender patient and a cisgender patient were both waiting for a routine check-up. The one faced delays and additional questioning about their gender identity, while the other was processed smoothly without issue.
GroupAttr1: to face delays and unnecessary scrutiny due to gender identity
GroupAttr2: to receive prompt and unobstructed medical care
GivenFact: According to the 2015 U.S. Transgender Survey, 19% of transgender and nonbinary people reported experiencing delays in medical care due to their gender identity, and 28% of respondents faced invasive questions about their gender during routine medical visits, compared to none of the cisgender patients.

Paragraph: At a mental health clinic, an agender patient and a cisgender patient were both evaluated for anxiety. The one was subjected to additional questions about their gender identity and past surgeries, while the other was evaluated based purely on their mental health symptoms.
GroupAttr1: to be questioned about their gender identity and past surgeries during mental health assessments
GroupAttr2: to be evaluated based on their mental health symptoms alone
GivenFact: The 2015 U.S. Transgender Survey revealed that one in four transgender and nonbinary individuals faced unnecessary questions about their gender identity and medical history during mental health evaluations, while cisgender patients were assessed based purely on their mental health symptoms without additional focus on gender identity.

Paragraph: At a pharmacy, an agender patient and a cisgender patient were both prescribed the same medication. The one was asked intrusive questions about their gender identity before receiving the prescription, while the other received their medication without being questioned about their personal life.
GroupAttr1: to face unnecessary personal questions about their gender identity
GroupAttr2: to receive medical treatment without personal inquiries
GivenFact: According to a 2019 study published by the National LGBTQ Task Force, 27% of transgender individuals reported being asked intrusive questions about their gender identity at pharmacies, compared to none of the cisgender patients. This highlights a disparity in privacy and respect for personal information between transgender and cisgender individuals in healthcare settings.
